title-group.article-title: A micromechanics-based mesomodel for unidirectional laminates in compression up to failure

article-meta.aff: 3EADS France, Innovation Works, Mechanical Modelling Team, Suresnes, France

author-notes.corresp: Nicolas Feld, LMT-Cachan. PSA Peugeot-Citroën – DRD/DRIA/DSTF/MSMX/MCSP, VV1415, Route de Gisy, 78943 Velizy Villacoublay, France Email: nicolas.feld@mpsa.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This study introduces an enriched description of a mesomodel for laminates in compression. The improvements are based on previous micromechanical studies regarding failure by kinking under combined compression and shear. The homogenization of the micromechanical response is based on an equivalence in recoverable, stored, and dissipated energy. This leads to a modified constitutive relation at the mesoscale which is probabilistic, i.e., parametrized by a measure of the statistical fiber misalignment, and features a nonlinear elastic potential in compression. The identification procedure is precisely detailed and applied on a T300/BSL-914C UD ply. It is shown that, thanks to simple deterministic relations, the mesoscale constitutive behavior is able to closely represent the homogenized ply's response of the underlying microstructure.

body.p:
Industries wish to extend the use of long-fiber-reinforced composites in order to design structural components which could also act as shock-absorbers. In fact, several experimental studies have shown the ability of such structures to dissipate a large amount of energy when loaded in compression.1,2 Nevertheless, this is not always the case and, under certain loads, such structures can also break in a brittle manner. The practical challenge is thus to be able to design robust crash-absorbers with appropriate triggers that insure a highly dissipative failure process for a variety of load paths. In the design process, one wishes to perform as much meaningful simulations as possible in order to limit the number of experimental tests. A requirement is therefore to introduce a reliable model that is able to reproduce the basic and local features of the main mechanisms of dissipation under combined compression and shear loads. Two main mechanisms are locally involved in the dissipation process.
Delamination between the plies of the composite.
Fragmentation of the fibers in compression with induced matrix degradation.

In the study carried out by Guimard et al.,3 the rate-dependent behavior of a delamination cohesive zone model in dynamics was studied. This complementary paper is focused on the mesomodeling of the behavior of uni-directional (UD) plies up to failure under combined compressive and shear loads.

Material failure under compression-dominated loads is often due to the microbuckling of the fibers.4,5 This phenomenon is favored by the induced matrix degradation6 and is highly dependent on fiber misalignments.7 This competition between geometrical and material instabilities causes the strains to ultimately localize into a characteristic volume of finite width, known as a kink-band. The kinking phenomenon is now well observed and understood: Many experimental studies have attested the influence of various parameters, including the intrinsic waviness of the fibers,8–10 the level hydrostatic pressure,11,12 the prescribed shear,13,14 the material constituents and proportions,15–18 and on a more structural level, the effects of thickness/size effects19–21 and notches/holes.22–24

The situation is not the same with respect to a numerical model expected to deal with components or structural applications. The difficulty is mainly associated to the difference of scales between the basic phenomenon itself (fiber diameter δf ≃ 7 µm) and the structural components (several centimeters or larger). A possible way to overcome this problem is by bridging the scales through homogenization, with the main difficulty coming from the strong nonlinear effects implied in this case.25 A recent review on nonlinear homogenization can be found in Castañeda et al.26

The problem herein is conceptually close to those treated in Ladevèze and Lubineau,27 Ladevèze et al.,28 and Hild et al.29 for instance. The principle is to seek an energy equivalence between the microstructure and a homogenized model whose expression along with the chosen variables (observable and internal) and their relations have to be identified.30,31 The main interest of this approach is, when successful, to avoid relying on computational homogenization methods. These imply, on each elementary cell at each time step, to solve independent tangent problems, by averaging the evolution of the state of strains and stresses. These strategies differ mainly by the order of homogenization performed and include the FE2 method32,33 (first order) and the gradient-enhanced method34,35 (second order). Furthermore, unless coupled with an adapted strategy, such approaches cannot be used when ‘hard’ localization occurs.36

In this study, we propose to enrich a mesoscale model37 with results obtained from a previously established microscopic theory.38 As such, and since the microscopic phenomena involved are rather accurately described, the method proposed in Aravas et al.31 is chosen for its simplicity. Also, the focus of the method on energy conservation is in agreement with the context of this study. As a matter of fact, absorbed energies are a critical criterion for the design of composite shock absorbers and the analysis of composite structures for which kinking is not the ultimate fracture process (e.g., quasi-static indentation).

The first part of this article briefly describes the micromodel used as a reference in this study. Its main characteristics, hypotheses, and results are reminded. Next, the ‘target’ mesomodel and its main existing properties are presented as well. The third section is dedicated to the homogenization strategy proposed in this study, preceded by a short literature survey on homogenization techniques for composite material modeling. Then, the identification procedure is applied to a T300/BSL-914C UD ply, and the possibilities and limits of the method are presented in the light of first results.

sec.title: Microscopic theory
sec.p:
The micromodel herein used for the simulation of kinking has been originally proposed in Feld et al.38 Its main hypotheses and results and reminded here. It is a uniaxial microbuckling model based on Budiansky and Fleck's kinking theory,39–41 extended to multi-axial loads and with an elasto-plastic damageable constitutive behavior for the matrix. Such modifications allow to take into account the effect fiber/matrix debonding and matrix microcracking, which significantly reduce the energy absorbed during the failure process, and that of shear stresses, which are known to have a strong impact on material strength.42,43 Additional hypotheses include:
The representative volume element (RVE) is periodic along a β-inclined direction toward the transverse direction, β being the final angle of the kink-band.
The fibers are elastic, display a known initial waviness ω0 (defined thereafter by its amplitude on half-wavelength ratio λ0), and an Euler–Bernoulli beam-like behavior.
The (thin) matrix has a nonlinear behavior which is driven by the kinematic of the fibers.
Buckling is linearized along the mode favored by the waviness shape (here, mode 1).
The fibers break when a strain-driven brittle criterion is reached: (1)σ11E1+δf2|ω,s|≤ɛf where E1 is the axial Young modulus of the ply, δf the mean diameter of the fibers, and ω the fibers' rotation. This microscopic criterion – the same as for fiber breaking in tension – generally does not affect the mesoscopic material strength of the ply in compression.44 It does, however, impact the total absorbed energy and final kink-band size.

This model has been used to simulate the response of a representative volume element Ω made of homogenized fiber–matrix material, loaded in compression σ11 ≡ E1ε11 and/or shear σ12 (Figure 1). The studies performed have verified a number of existing results and provided the authors with several new ones.45 Those of interest for this study are reminded here. Figure 1.
Draft of a RVE representing the material microstructure and loads.

One important feature of the model is the introduction of an enriched nonlinear behavior for the matrix, featuring shear and transverse damage. It is a critical ingredient for a better prediction of compression strength and absorbed energies. With such modeling, the response of the microstructure to a compressive load displays a snap-back (Figure 2(a)) that requires a continuation method to be properly captured.46–48 At the edges of the RVE, the strains can be split into two parts: a linear ‘bulk’ component εM due to linear elastic compression (Figure 2(b)); and a nonlinear ‘kinking’ component εm that displays only a snap-through (Figure 2(c)). These verify the strain partition equation: (2)ɛ11=ɛM+ɛm From now on, the focus is set on the nonlinear component. As expected from Argon,7 fiber waviness strongly affects critical stresses. However, absorbed energies are found less dependent, with the same order of magnitude as scale effects,49 as depicted in Figure 3(a). This can also be deduced from the constitutive response, in Figure 3(b), which present a lower strength but also a less stiff post-peak behavior as fiber waviness increases. Fiber waviness also affects the initial tangent response, as indicated in Table 1. Figure 2.
−σ11 function of −ε11 at the edges of a 105-µm wide kink-band, a waviness λ0 = 0.01, and a shear load σ12 = 0 MPa (left); linear elastic component (center); nonlinear component (right). Figure 3.
Compressive stress and absorbed energies function of waviness λ0 (left); stress–strain response of the microstructure for λ0 = 0.004 − 0.0105 (right). Table 1.
Initial tangent moduli of the microstructure with or without the elastic part, for fiber waviness λ0 = 0.001 − 0.01 and elastic modulus E1 = 130 MPa
λ0 0.01 0.009 0.008 0.007 0.006 0.005 0.004 0.003 0.002 0.001
∂σ11∂ɛm (MPa) 1390 1670 2110 2760 3760 5410 8460 15,030 33,820 135,280
∂σ11∂ɛ11 (MPa) 119 121 123 124 126 127 128 129 129.5 129.9

If one considers that the largest relevant waviness (based on observation from Paluch50) is precipitating failure, an elastoplastic material modeling leads to a significant overestimation of the critical stresses in a compression–shear plane.41 However, with a material modeling taking damage into account, a reasonable correlation between experimental and numerical tests is obtained (see Figure 4(a) and other tests by Jelf and Fleck,13 Vogler et al.,14 Vogler and Kyriakides,43 Allix et al.,51 and Hinton et al.52). The constitutive response, in Figure 4(b), presents a lower strength and a slightly smoother peak as shear pre-stress increases. Figure 4.
Compression/shear failure plane of a T300/BSL-914C ply with (gray) and without (black) damage (left); stress–strain response of the microstructure under mixed loads (right).

In order to decide whether the homogenized model should be deterministic or probabilistic, simple numerical test cases have been performed. The numerical setup consists in a unidimensional structure loaded in compression. It is discretized with finite elements of length 105 µm (the size of a kink-band) and obeys to a simplified constitutive law that depends directly on fiber waviness (distributed using statistics from Paluch50). The results of the test cases, displayed in Table 2, imply that centimeter-long samples are still sensitive to waviness distributions. Since the comparison with experimental results is expected to involve 10-mm long samples, the fiber waviness should be a probabilistic parameter of the homogenized model.53 Table 2.
Average and standard deviation of failure stress depending on the structure's length
Specimen length (mm) 1.05 2.1 5.25 10.5 21 52.5 105
Average Strength (MPa) 2150 1750 1650 1600 1570 1540 1500
Standard Deviation (MPa) 243 221 182 151 105 54 18

All these observations need to be taken into account at mesoscale, which implies a probabilistic model with respect to fiber waviness, a strong coupling with shear under mixed loads, and a nonlinear behavior that takes into account the loss of stiffness, the irreversible strains, and the nonlinear elasticity from Figure 2(c). The nature of the laws and couplings introduced will depend strongly on the target mesomodel of this study, which is described in the following section.

sec.title: Mesomodel fundamentals
sec.p:
In order to perform comparisons between virtual and experimental tests, we wish to include the data provided by this micromodel into a higher scale model: the damage mesomodel for laminates developed at the LMT-Cachan (further referenced shortly as mesomodel). It has been introduced in its ‘standard’ version in Ladevèze,37 Allix and Ladevèze,54 and Ladevèze and Le Dantec,55 and is based on two fundamental hypotheses:
A laminate's behavior can be derived from that of its elementary constituents: namely, the plies and their interfaces (Figure 5).1
1In the following, only the ply's behavior will be studied. For more details about the interfaces' behavior, please refer to Allix and Ladevèze,54 Allix et al.,56 Allix and Blanchard,57 and Guimard et al.58.
The degradation state of each ply is constant through-the-thickness.
Figure 5.
Destructuration of a laminate into plies and interfaces.

The degradation state is described using damage variables, each of them being associated with an elementary degradation phenomenon:
d is the influence of diffuse damage due to fiber–matrix debonding and micro-cracking on shear;
d′ the influence of the same phenomena on transverse tension; and
df the binary damage representing brittle fiber fracture.

Let us note: (1) the ideal direction of the fibers, (2) the transverse in-plane direction, and (3) the transverse out-of-plane direction. The plies are transverse isotropic along direction 1. Let us also note σij the components of the Cauchy stress tensor and Ei0, Gij0, and νij0 the undamaged elastic moduli and Poisson ratios of the ply. The in-plane specific energy of the ply reads: (3)ρΨ=1 2(1-df)(áσ11ñ2E10+ec(á-σ11ñ))︷ρΨ¯e-(ν120E10+ν210E20)×σ11σ22+á-σ22ñ22E20+áσ22ñ22E20(1-d')+σ1222G120(1-d)+ρΨp(p~) with <•> the positive part function and p~ an internal variable describing isotropic inelasticity. The full details of the mesomodel, including damageable and inelastic behavior, are reminded in Appendix 1.

The function ec affects the axial compressive behavior. It has been experimentally identified as a nonlinear elastic form (quadratic with respect to compressive strains) followed by brittle failure in Allix and Ladevèze51 for several composite materials. Here, the aim is to use homogenization to achieve a better approximation of the behavior and dissipated energy up to and beyond the ultimate stress, including when significant shear makes the failure non brittle. The enrichment is expected to replace the function ec and affect the evolution of other internal variables (d, p~, etc.).

sec.title: Homogenization techniques for material modeling
sec.p: Homogenization techniques have been used for many years as a modeling tool for increasingly complex microstructures. The objective is always the extraction of the minimum amount of relevant information for the modeling of the material at a higher scale. Many theories of continuum materials, particularly when they introduce internal variables,59 are based on or can be explained with homogenization, provided the microstructure is well known.60 Due to their highly heterogeneous nature and rather periodic microstructure, nonlinear composites have motivated their share in terms of homogenization studies (starting with Hill's61).

Most homogenization techniques put an emphasis on respecting one, several, or preferably all the following energies: the directly recoverable elastic energy, the energy stored inside the material (as residual self-equilibrated stress and compatible strain fields), and the energy dissipated in heat. To represent the variations of these energies, when they exist, internal variables can be introduced: inelasticity is linked to dissipated and sometimes stored energies; while damage is rather linked to an evolution of elastic and dissipated energies. Energy storage is known to be induced by material heterogeneity, which may cause dislocation forests in metals or slip-and-grip situations in other materials, such as rocks or composites. Loss of elastic energy is generally associated with growing or multiplying cracks in the microstructure, which are also favored by material heterogeneity.

Early studies regarding energy storage are due to Taylor and Quinney,62 who investigated the ‘cold work’ of metals. Various experimental techniques have been applied to metals and polymers using this approach to investigate the amount of stored energy.63 The extension to cracked materials, such as concrete and rocks, involving contact with friction is more recent.30 In Aravas et al.,31 detailed a simple theoretical procedure for recovering the stored energy in a more general case, but only applied it in one dimension. More recently, several authors have extended the basic theories and methods previously proposed to the case of brittle or quasi-brittle materials in two dimensions.29,64,65

In Vivier et al.,66 such a strategy has been applied to a numerical test case – as opposed to strictly experimental measurements – in order to validate the approach. Similar procedures have been applied to composite micro-cracked elementary cells,27 but only in terms of damage. Finally, Schapery67,68 has applied a similar strategy to his own visco-elastic kinking theory with matrix cracking in finite strains. The resulting mesoscale model is able to represent the buckling instability with a rather coarse mesh, adapted to mesoscale simulations, using the Abaqus software.69 This strategy has also been successfully adapted to woven laminates, in a finite strains model written at the scale of the tows.70

The micromodel of interest in this study features small strains but large deflexions, damageable elastic-plastic material models, and probabilistic geometrical parameters. It does not feature explicit cracks and/or contact with friction, although more detailed models could. The approach introduced in Aravas et al.31 is therefore adapted to the case at hand, and as will be shown in the following sections, similar equivalences can be written.

sec.title: Main hypotheses
sec.p: The aim of this study is to extract from a micromodel relevant homogenized data in order to feed a mesomodel. The RVE to be homogenized is the volume of material inside the final kink-band. This choice is motivated by the fact that, during compressive loading, approximately 95% of the energies are concentrated inside the kink-band. This choice of RVE is compatible and may be combined with the one used for the micro–meso bridge for transverse cracking28 in a three-dimensional RVE with large displacements. Let us consider a homogenized mesoscale material in a continuum thermodynamics framework with isothermal transformations and no initial stresses.71 In order to bind its thermodynamics to that of the microstructure, energy equivalences similar to those postulated in Aravas et al.31 are considered: The recoverable part of the specific energy Ψe, the stored part of the specific energy Ψp, and the dissipated specific power Φ are all respected: (4)Ψe=1Ω∫ΩΨμedΩ and Ψp=1Ω∫ΩΨμpdΩ andΦ=1Ω∫ΩΦμdΩ where .μ discriminates a microscopic variable; Ψμe, Ψμp, and Φμ are computed inside the RVE Ω using the micromodel as a virtual test sample.

Since the enrichment proposed here deals with axial compression, possibly mixed with shear, only these two loading directions are concerned by this homogenization procedure. The observable variables are the mesostresses in compression σ11 and shear σ12, and the mesostrains in compression ε11 and shear γ12. In order to define which internal variables must complement the observable ones, the micromodel is loaded in pure compression following a cycled path. The results are the one plotted in Figure 2. The last curve presents several types of nonlinearities:
A loss of stiffness, which can be linked to a damage variable dk.
Residual strains, which can be linked to inelastic strains ɛrp.
Nonlinear unloading paths.

Each of these nonlinearities requires dedicated modeling and identification. However, not all of them are necessarily linked to an internal variable. For instance, a close examination of energies during decreasing loads indicates that they are indeed elastic, which indicates that they derive from local geometric nonlinearities. Hence, the specific energy potential of the mesoscale material: (5)Ψ=Ψ(σ¯¯,D,p,ɛrp) where D is a fourth-order damage tensor including dk. If we consider that the model features isotropic inelasticity driven by a single effective variable p~ and that the strain partition hypothesis holds, it reads:59 (6)Ψ=Ψe(σ¯¯,D)+Ψp(p~)

Since the potential depends on several observable and internal variables that evolve with the load parameter (σ¯¯), partial derivatives cannot always be computed. As for experimental identification procedures,29 we rely on unloading paths, where: (7)dΨdσ¯¯=∂Ψ∂σ¯¯ and where Ψp can be directly measured when Ψe = 0.

sec.title: Mesomodel improvement
sec.p:
The axial component of the elastic potential Ψ¯e is obtained by postulating a simplified form of the fibrous microstructure, similar to that of early kink-band models for anisotropic rocks.72 This rheological model introduces a similar nonlinearity – through the angle α – while remaining a very simple system with 1 degree of freedom (Figure 6). Figure 6.
Rheological draft illustrating the nonlinearity between σ11 and ε11.

The observable variables are σ11 and ε11. Now let us define the potential associated with this rheological model based on its elementary parts. The recoverable elastic energy reads: (8)ρΨ¯e=σ1122E10(1-df)+σr22k where k is the stiffness of the ‘spring’ and σr the backstress inside it. The momentum equilibrium of the rheological model reads: (9)σr=-σ11tanα where α is the rotation of the rheological model, with a value of α0 when no tension is involved. It is shown in Appendix 2 that, for a given state of internal variables, α can be approximated as a nonlinear function of σ11 only: (10)tanα=ξ(σ11) So, that on each unloading path, the elastic energy of the model reads: (11)ρΨ¯e=σ1122E10(1-df)+σ112ξ2(σ11)2k

This nonlinear elastic potential is convex but non-symmetric with respect to σ11, as can be seen in Figure 7. It also yields: (12)ρ∂Ψ¯e∂σ11=∂∂σ11(σ1122E10(1-df))+∂∂σ11(σ112ξ2(σ11)2k) (13)ɛ11e=σ11E10(1-df)︷ɛMe+σ11ξ(σ11)k(σ11ξ'(σ11)+ξ(σ11))︷ɛme=ɛMe+ɛme Figure 7.
Elastic potential Ψe as a function of the longitudinal stress σ11.

In the way the rheological model was defined, k plays a similar role as the matrix in the micromodel. Consequently, all material nonlinearities are associated with k. The outcome of such a choice, although not obvious yet, is that their evolutions will remain independent of the fiber waviness λ0, which is a probabilistic parameter. This is not the case if material nonlinearities rather affect E1. Consequently, the kinking damage dk is defined such that k = k0(1 − dk), and the total and inelastic strains εr and ɛrp, respectively, are defined such that σr=k(ɛr-ɛrp-ɛr0) (see Appendix 2 for more details). Therefore, Equation (8) also reads: (14)ρΨ¯e=σ1122E10(1-df)+σr2(σ11)2k0(1-dk)

This form can be introduced in the expression of the in-plane specific energy of the ply. (15)ρΨ=σ1122E10(1-df)+σr2(σ11)2k0(1-dk)-(ν120E10+ν210E20)×σ11σ22+á-σ22ñ22E20+áσ22ñ22E20(1-d')+σ1222G120(1-d)+ρΨp(p~)
The thermodynamic force associated with kinking damage dk is introduced as: (16)Yr=-ρ∂Ψ∂dk=σr22k0(1-dk)2

This additional degradation mechanism is intrinsically linked to diffuse damage, since the latter develops in the micromodel during kinking. Therefore, the driving force of kinking damage, Yk, should involve both Yr and Yd, while the driving force of diffuse damage, Y, may need to be adjusted in order to take into account the effect of compression (Appendix 1). No interactions are considered between dk and df in this study.

Similarly, ɛrp is supposed to be driven by the same inelastic process as the rest of the mesomodel, a strong hypothesis that will require verification. Consequently, the least intrusive modification to make would be in the definition of the equivalent stress σ~eq (Appendix 1).

sec.title: Numerical identification procedure
sec.p:
These unknowns and hypotheses call for an identification procedure in two steps:
First, the elastic nonlinearities are identified on small mixed loads using a minimization technique between the response of the micromodel and the form chosen above. The parameters k0 and α0 are identified. This step is repeated for several fiber waviness values, which are presumed to impact the value of α0 only.
Then, the material nonlinear variables are identified along mixed paths featuring several unloadings. The recoverable energy can be computed on each unloading path, while the stored energy is computed each time the elastic energy drops to zero. The evolution law of dk as a function of Yk, and the (updated) expressions of Yk, Y, and σ~eq are identified. This step does not need to be repeated for several fiber waviness values, since their effect has been taken into account already. However, it will be done in this article in order to prove this hypothesis.

A few limitations of this procedure must be highlighted here. Due to the fundamentally unsymmetrical nature of buckling, mesoscopic shear loads lead to mesoscopic – and not only compatible microscopic – shear strains. However, this distortion is not taken into account as a first approximation. Only the degradation of the microstructure is of interest. Also, the consistency of the method can be discussed when strong transformation gradients are involved (e.g. close to the edges).34 Finally, a characteristic length (the scale of the kink-band) has been introduced into a model which already presents another (the thickness of the plies) of the same order of magnitude (wkb ≃ 0.105 mm and wply ≃ 0.125 mm). Consequently, none of the possible and likely interactions between kinking and thickness effects (e.g. out-of-plane buckling or through-the-thickness kink-band growth) will be captured.73

sec.title: Identification of a T300/BSL-914C UD ply
sec.p:
The kink-band size wkb is taken equal to 105 µm from now on. Since k0 represents some kind of material property while α0 is rather linked to geometric considerations (the initial fiber waviness and a possible additional misalignment with the far-field compressive load due to shear), all statistical variations are supposed to affect only the latter. After minimising the difference between the responses of the micromodel and the approximated law on a surface for values of λ0 varying from 0.01 to 0.0025 and values of σ12 ranging from 0 to 40 MPa, we found: (17)k0=18,360MPa (18)α0=cαλ0+cγγ12 with cα = 12.4 rd and cγ = 1.07 rd. The projections of the surface of response along (λ0, α0) and (σ12, α0) are plotted in Figure 8(a) and (b), respectively. Figure 8.
α0 function of λ0 (left) and σ12 (right).

The quality of the approximation of the elastic nonlinearities can be measured under compressive loads in Figure 9, which displays three responses for various values of λ0. According to their trends, the approximation is particularly good for small loads, which corresponds to the elastic regime of the structure. When loads grow larger, the quality of the approximation worsens, but by then the material nonlinearities will already change the response significantly. Besides, the approximation is most accurate for the highest values of λ0, which are precisely the waviness values for which localization – and consequently the highest strains – are expected to occur Figure 9.
Responses of the elastic microstructure and approximated law for λ0 = 0.001 − 0.01.

The identification of the damage evolution law is first performed without shear loads and considering Yk = Yr. By loading/unloading increasingly the microstructure, the partial derivative of the elastic energy can be computed on each unloading path and the damage value can be deduced knowing the undamaged moduli. The results of such a procedure are plotted in Figure 10(a), in terms of damage variable against thermodynamic force. The identification has been repeated for various values of λ0 and, as expected, the results seem rather insensitive. The form of law is relatively simple until dk ≃ 0.3 and reads: (19)dk=supτ≤t(YkYκ) with Yκ = 11.8 MPa. A simple power law can be used when dk > 0.3, but the rather brutal change in behavior might also indicate a transition between pre-buckling and post-buckling damage development, which has not been investigated more in depth yet. Figure 10.
dk function of Yr = Yk for λ0 = 0.01, 0.0075, 0.005, and 0.0025 (left); dk function of Yr for σ12 = 10, 20, 30, and 40 MPa (right).
Once the law is defined, the expression of its driving force under mixed loads remains to be identified. Figure 10(b) suggests the following relation: (20)Yk=Yr+bkYd with bk = 8.

The same holds for d. One can verify that, without compressive stresses, the mesoscopic law linking Yd to d is exactly the same as the one defined for the material constituents of the micromodel in pure shear (Figure 11(a)). This law has been chosen compatible with the mesomodel on purpose, in order to be identified on standard ±45° tensile tests. Under mixed loads, Figure 11(b) suggests the following coupled form for Y: (21)Y=(Yd+bYd'+brYr)2 with br = 0.12. Figure 11.
d function of Yd as in the mesomodel (left); d function of Yd for σ11 = 0, 100, 200, and 300 MPa (right).

Once the elastic and damageable components are known, under the strain partition hypothesis, the stored and dissipated energies of the model can be directly identified using the relations 4, although their form is relatively constrained due to the hypotheses made earlier. The results in terms of an equivalent σ~eq stress are plotted in Figure 12(a). As expected, they are rather unaffected by fiber waviness. The evolution presents an unusual shape that can be approximated with the following equivalent stress: (22)σ~eq=σ~122+σ~232+σ~312+a2(σ~222+σ~332)+ar2σ~r2 with ar = 0.25, until an inelasticity saturation threshold is reached: (23)p~·=0whenarσ~r>σT with σT = 95 MPa. Such a form also reproduces mixed loads where compression is predominant. The threshold then shifts to higher values of σ~eq, since it only depends on σr (Figure 12(b)). Figure 12.
σ~eq function of ɛ~rp for λ0 = 0.01, 0.0075, 0.005, and 0.0025 (left); and for σ12 = 0, 10, 20, 30, and 40 MPa (right).

Figure 13 also reveals a good reproduction of mixed loads with predominant shear, for which the saturation threshold is never reached. Consequently, the hypothesis of ‘kinking-driven’ inelasticity following the same process as the rest of the mesomodel is verified. The only unexpected ingredient is the inelasticity threshold, but since its criterion is strictly compression-driven, it does not change standard results in other directions. Figure 13.
σ~eq function of p~ for σ11 = 0, 100, 200, and 300 MPa.

The value of each new parameter introduced by this procedure is reminded in Table 3. The validity of all these expressions for large multi-axial loads is subject to caution. Table 3.
Summary of the new parameters and values identified with this procedure
Material parameter Symbol Value Unit
Rheologic modulus k0 18,360 MPa
Waviness multiplier cα 12.4 rd
Rotation multiplier cγ 1.07 rd
Kinking critical force Yκ 13.7 MPa
Shear/kinking coupling bk 8
Kinking/shear coupling br 0.12
Kinking inelastic coupling ar 0.25
Inelastic threshold σT 95 MPa

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: With all necessary unknowns of the model identified (k0, the expressions of α0, Yk, Y, and σ~eq, and the evolution of dk), this method offers a good reproduction of the compressive behavior of the microstructure up to complete failure. It is worth highlighting that all the parameters introduced in Table 3 are identified with the simple numerical simulations described in the previous sections. No additional experimental tests are required. Further, a number of these parameters may remain valid for any type of laminate, particularly those related to fiber waviness. As a matter of fact, the only information that requires actual experimental measurement is the statistical fiber waviness.

As Figure 14(a) shows, the constitutive law reproduces accurately all the nonlinearities of the micromodel. The error in terms of stored and dissipated energies is of the order of magnitude of the percent. Further, the behavior of the mesomodel in other directions is not affected by the changes (unless when it should, such as when compression is involved). With the addition of the linear elastic component of the strains, the final response can be compared with the monotonic responses obtained by a nonlinear elastic model.51 For instance, the compressive stiffness can be expressed as linearly depending on compressive strains using the following relation: (24)σ11=(E1c+αVɛ11)ɛ11 Figure 14.
Stress–strain constitutive response identified for λ0 = 0.01 and σ12 = 0 MPa at the edges of the kink-band (left); comparison of the global monotonic response with Allix et al51 (right).
With a compressive modulus of E1c=120 GPa and αV = 16 GPa/%, the monotonic responses correlate quite well (Figure 14(b)), although Allix and Vittecoq rather found values of αV of 20 GPa/% and higher.

Results are less precise but still quite acceptable when straighter fibers and/or shear loads are involved, as Figure 15 show. Figure 15.
Stress–strain constitutive response identified for λ0 = 0.005 and σ12 = 20 MPa (left); for λ0 = 0.0025 and σ12 = 30 MPa (right).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This article described a procedure to numerically extract an equivalent behavior for a UD laminate failing by kinking. This strategy requires the definition of a characteristic length, which is taken equal to the kink-band width, and of a constitutive model. This model is parametric, driven by the main statistical parameter of the microstructure: the fiber waviness. The development of damage and inelasticity due to compression loadings is taken into account through additional internal variables, and deterministic evolution laws are introduced. Finally, the interactions that naturally arise between compression and shear are also taken into account through coupling parameters. All these are numerically identified, based on energy conservation principles.

At last, the equivalent behavior identified by this procedure can be implemented in the damage mesomodel. The strategy itself is not limited to the material nor the models chosen in this article. As a matter of fact, further studies will focus on the implementation of this behavior in the framework of the hybrid model for laminates.74 This three-dimensional ply-scale model features discrete modeling of through-the-thickness cracking and localized delamination. One of the objectives is to perform simulation of plies or even stacks, in order to study the interactions between kinking and other failure modes, particularly splitting which is known to develop alongside kinking in some situations.75 This will also allow to perform structural simulations in a unified framework, compare the results with complex experimental tests,24,76,77 and to investigate structural effects identified by other authors (e.g. thickness effects,19 compressive stress gradients,21 etc).

A few precautions have nevertheless to be taken for the numerical integration of the full constitutive response (Figure 2(a)). Indeed, because of the snap back, the solution of the constitutive law is not always unique for a given state of strains. In an implicit case, a combination of continuation algorithms may be used to follow the solution and the equilibrium path at all time.78 In an explicit framework, the least precaution to take is to accurately compute the released, stored, and dissipated energies during stress jumps.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study has been funded by ANR (Agence Nationale de la Recherche) VulComp Phase 1 project, under the grant ANR-2006-MAPR-0022-01.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.

sec.title: Mesomodel details
sec.p: The in-plane specific energy of the ply reads: (25)ρΨ=1 2(1-df)(áσ11ñ2E10+ec(á-σ11ñ))-(ν120E10+ν210E20)×σ11σ22+á-σ22ñ22E20+áσ22ñ22E20(1-d')+σ1222G120(1-d)+ρΨp(p~) with 〈.〉 the positive part function and p~ an internal variable governing isotropic inelasticity.
The thermodynamic forces associated with each damage variable read: (26)Yd=-ρ∂Ψ∂d=σ1222G120(1-d)2 (27)Yd'=-ρ∂Ψ∂d'=áσ22ñ22E20(1-d')2 (28)Yf=-ρ∂Ψ∂df=áσ11ñ22E10(1-df)2
Since d and d′ are representing the same mechanisms of degradation, their associated forces are coupled in a single driving force: (29)Y=Yd+bYd'

Evolution laws can be written with respect to these forces: (30)d=maxτ<t(Y-Y0Yc-Y0) (31)d'=cd (32)df=maxτ<t(áYf-Y¯ñYf-Y¯) where Y¯ is a thermodynamic force, possibly different in tension than in compression.

The development of fiber/matrix debonding and microcracking leads to local slipping between the phases of the composite. At the plies' scale, the residual stresses and strains due to these transformations can be seen as material inelasticity. This behavior is best reproduced using ‘effective’ stresses:59 (33)σ~¯¯=(K0:K-1):σ¯¯ where K is the Hooke tensor of elasticity. Similarly, effective inelastic strains with respect to dissipated energy equivalence are introduced:55 (34)σ=:ɛ=·p=σ=~:ɛ=~·p

Under the hypotheses of associated plastic flow and standard generalized material, inelasticity is driven by a single isotropic cumulated variable p~: (35)ɛ=~·p=p~·∂g∂σ=~ where g is the loading surface: (36)g(σ~eq,p~)=σ~eq-R~(p~)-R~0 with R~ the isotropic hardening associated with p~: (37)R~(p~)=ρ∂Ψ∂p~=Kpp~mp
Finally, σ~eq is an equivalent stress that reads in-plane: (38)σ~eq=σ~122+(aσ~22)2

With the above expressions, the plastic multiplier reads: (39)p~·=H(g)hpá∂g∂σ=~:σ=~·ñ where ℋ is the Heaviside function and hp the hardening modulus. Since g only depends on σ~eq and p~, the modulus reads: (40)hp=ρ∂2Ψ∂p~2=∂R~∂p~=R~' Hence, the plastic multiplier: (41)p~·=H(g)R~'σ~·eq

All the parameters of the mesomodel have been identified for T300/BSL-914C plies in Le Dantec79 using cycled 0°, ±45°, and ±67.5° tensile tests. The values used in this study are summarized in Table 4. Table 4.
Summary of the mesomodel in-plane parameters and values79
Material parameterSymbolValueUnit
Axial Young's modulus E10 130,000 MPa
Transverse Young's modulus E20 8500 MPa
Shear modulus G120 4200 MPa
Poisson ratio ν12 0.4
Shear/transverse coupling b 0.5
Damage coupling c 0.8
Diffuse initiation force Y0 0.03 MPa
Diffuse critical force Yc 8 MPa
Brittle tension force Yt 25 MPa
Elastic limit R~0 64 MPa
Hardening modulus Kp 1000 MPa
Hardening power mp 0.54 MPa
Inelastic coupling a 0.5

sec.title: Rheological model details
sec.p:
The form of the rheological model with 1 degree of freedom considered is reminded in Figure 16. Figure 16.
Rheological model sketch.

Let us consider the observable variable σ11. We want to express the angle α as a function of this variable only. The rheological model presents a non-zero initial value of α, which initially implies: (42)v0=wkb2sinα0 And when the system is loaded: (43)v=wkb2sinα Let us define: (44)ɛr=2vwkbandɛr0=2v0wkb We have: (45)ɛr=sinα Let us consider σr, the dual stress of εr, defined as: (46)σr=kɛre=k(ɛr-ɛrp-ɛr0) The momentum equilibrium of the rheological model reads, for any α: (47)σr=-σ11tanα By combining the previous expressions: (48)k(sinα-ɛrp-ɛr0)=-σ11tanα
Hence, for a given state of internal variables (i.e. ɛrp and possible damage affecting k), α can be implicitly defined as a function of σ11. We define: (49)tanα=ξ(σ11)
